stories.title: Back to the Future of Twitter

stories.text:
This happened to me on a debit card a couple weeks ago, then to a bunch of colleagues more recently with Brex cards. All alerted that fraudulent attempts were made to use the cards at online merchants (Spotify, Shopify, etc.), i.e. card not present transactions, but some detail (cvv, expiration, etc.) of the card didn't match.

I hadn't used that debit card in over a year, and when I called my bank to cancel my debit card, they said that the Spotify charges were common attempts where bad guys just try card numbers to then see if the card was valid.

I've often wondered, there aren't THAT many digits of randomization in a payment card number (6 digits are the bin number, 1 is the luhn checksum), so I don't think it would be that hard, for example, to have a bot network just try tons of numbers at various online merchants.

Is this just paranoia, or has anyone else seen an uptick in these kinds of card-denied transactions?
stories.title: Ask HN: Anyone else seeing an uptick in fraudulent declined credit/debit cards?

stories.text: For the last two years it seems like every story about pro-mask, pro-lockdown, pro-covid fear mongering is on the HN front page. Yet, in a landmark case, a Florida federal court just struck it down and masks are no longer required at airports and on planes. If you don't think there is a obvious political bias and censoring happening on HN you aren't paying attention. How can a story this important to our freedoms be silenced and censored?
stories.title: Ask HN: The mask mandate was just struck down in federal court, yet no stories?

stories.text:
Do you each individually use {Gmail|Outlook|Yahoo} and call it a day?

Do you have a family domain and then provide each member a unique email address? Self-hosted? Was your last name actually available as a .com domain or did you choose something different?

Do you do something else entirely?

Please share your setup and design decisions.
